title: Multiplication on the Soroban: A Complete Parent's Guide to Teaching Times Tables and Beyond
description: Master soroban multiplication with this comprehensive guide. Learn how to teach single-digit, multi-digit, and advanced multiplication using the Japanese abacus method.

content.intro: As a middle school math teacher for 15 years, I've watched hundreds of students struggle with multiplication. The times tables feel arbitrary. Multi-digit multiplication seems like magic. Then I discovered the soroban and taught it to my own four children. Suddenly, multiplication made sense. They could see why 23 × 4 = 92, not just memorize it. In this guide, I'll share the exact methods I've used to teach soroban multiplication – from basic times tables through complex multi-digit problems – and explain why this visual approach creates deeper mathematical understanding.

sections.text: Why Soroban Multiplication is Different

Traditional multiplication instruction asks children to memorize: 7 × 8 = 56. They rarely understand why. Soroban multiplication shows the process physically. Your child sees 7 groups of 8 beads accumulating into 56. This visual understanding transfers to mental math and creates lasting comprehension.

Soroban multiplication fundamentally means: multiply digit by digit, place products in correct columns, then add everything up. It's the same as traditional long multiplication, but with physical manipulation that reveals the logic.
Prerequisites: What Your Child Needs First
Don't rush into multiplication. My biggest teaching mistake was introducing it too early with my oldest son. He wasn't ready, got frustrated, and we had to step back. Learn from my experience.

items: **Solid addition:** Can perform 2-3 digit addition fluently
**Comfortable carrying:** 10-complement should be automatic, not struggled
**Basic subtraction:** Needed for checking work and understanding
**Times tables 1-5:** At minimum; 1-9 is better before starting
**Place value:** Understands ones, tens, hundreds positions

sections.text: Most children are ready for soroban multiplication after 2-3 months of consistent addition and subtraction practice. But readiness varies – watch for confident, automatic bead manipulation before proceeding.
Starting Simple: Single-Digit × Single-Digit
Begin with problems your child already knows the answers to. The goal isn't calculation at first – it's understanding the soroban method.
Example: 3 × 4

items: **Step 1:** Think '3 × 4' and recall the product: 12
**Step 2:** Set 12 on the soroban (1 in tens column, 2 in ones)
**Step 3:** Verify: Does 1 ten and 2 ones equal 12? Yes!

sections.text: Wait, that seems too simple. You're right – for single digits where you know the answer, soroban just helps you set the result. The real learning happens with larger numbers.
Two-Digit × Single-Digit: Where the Magic Begins
This is where soroban multiplication shines. Let's work through 12 × 3 step by step.
Example: 12 × 3

items: **Step 1:** Start with the tens digit: 1 (which represents 10) × 3 = 3 (representing 30)
**Step 2:** Set 30 on the soroban (3 in tens column)
**Step 3:** Now the ones digit: 2 × 3 = 6
**Step 4:** Add 6 to the ones column
**Step 5:** Read result: 30 + 6 = 36 ✓

sections.text: The key insight: Multiply each digit separately, placing products in their correct place value, then add. This is exactly what long multiplication does on paper, but with visible bead manipulation.
Example: 23 × 4

items: **Step 1:** Tens digit first: 2 × 4 = 8 (represents 80)
**Step 2:** Set 80 on soroban (8 in tens column = heaven bead + 3 earth beads)
**Step 3:** Ones digit: 3 × 4 = 12
**Step 4:** Add 12 to existing 80. The '2' goes in ones, the '1' carries to tens
**Step 5:** Read result: 80 + 12 = 92 ✓

sections.text: My daughter struggled with Step 4 initially. I had her verbalize: '80 plus 12. The 2 goes here, and the 1 carries.' Speaking the process helped internalize it.
Practice Problems: Two-Digit × Single-Digit
Have your child work through these systematically before moving to harder problems.

items: **11 × 2 = 22** (Easy start, no carrying)
**21 × 3 = 63** (Slightly larger, still no carrying)
**13 × 4 = 52** (First carrying required)
**24 × 3 = 72** (Carrying practice)
**35 × 2 = 70** (Larger numbers)
**17 × 5 = 85** (Times 5 practice)

sections.text: Three-Digit × Single-Digit
The same principle extends to three digits. Start from the leftmost digit, work right.
Example: 234 × 2

items: **Step 1:** Hundreds: 2 × 2 = 4 (400). Set 400.
**Step 2:** Tens: 3 × 2 = 6 (60). Add 60 to get 460.
**Step 3:** Ones: 4 × 2 = 8. Add 8 to get 468.

sections.text: Notice the pattern: We always work left to right (hundreds → tens → ones), and we ADD each partial product to the running total. This mirrors mental math strategies.
Two-Digit × Two-Digit: The Full Challenge
Now we multiply both digits of the multiplicand by both digits of the multiplier. This is where place value understanding becomes crucial.
Example: 23 × 14
Think of this as: 23 × 10 + 23 × 4

items: **Part 1:** 23 × 10 = 230. Set 230 on soroban.
**Part 2:** 23 × 4 = 92. Add to existing 230.

sections.text: Or more broken down (how I taught my younger children):

items: **Result:** 322 ✓

sections.text: The Visualization Advantage

What makes soroban multiplication powerful isn't speed – it's understanding. When my son calculates 23 × 14, he's not following a mysterious algorithm. He's physically building the answer from components he understands.

items: **Place value becomes concrete:** The tens column IS the tens place
**Carrying makes sense:** Overflow physically moves to the next column
**Errors become visible:** Miscounts show up as wrong bead patterns
**Mental math develops:** The visualization transfers to calculation without beads

sections.text: Common Mistakes and Solutions
After teaching four children and tutoring dozens more, I've catalogued the most common multiplication errors.

items: **Forgetting place value:** Child multiplies 2 × 4 = 8 but forgets the 2 represents 20. Solution: Always verbalize '2 TENS times 4 equals 8 TENS'
**Skipping partial products:** Child forgets to multiply all digit pairs. Solution: Use a checklist – cross off each multiplication as completed
**Carrying errors:** Adding the carried digit incorrectly. Solution: Practice carrying separately before combining with multiplication
**Working right-to-left:** Traditional order doesn't work well on soroban. Solution: Emphasize left-to-right consistently

sections.text: Building Speed: The Practice Progression
Speed comes from automaticity, not rushing. Here's the progression I recommend.

items: **Week 1-2:** Single-digit × single-digit, focus on proper technique
**Week 3-4:** Two-digit × single-digit without carrying
**Week 5-6:** Two-digit × single-digit with carrying
**Week 7-8:** Three-digit × single-digit
**Week 9-12:** Two-digit × two-digit
**Ongoing:** Speed drills only after accuracy is consistent

sections.text: My rule: 90% accuracy before moving to the next level. If your child gets more than 1 in 10 wrong, stay at the current level longer.
Connecting to School Math
One unexpected benefit: my children found school multiplication easier after learning soroban. The long multiplication algorithm made sense because they'd already experienced its logic physically.

items: **Times tables:** Soroban practice reinforces memorization through repetition
**Long multiplication:** The partial products method is identical to soroban method
**Mental math:** Visualization skills transfer directly
**Estimation:** Understanding place value improves estimation ability

sections.text: When to Introduce Multiplication
Based on my experience with my own children and students, here are the readiness indicators.

items: **Time:** After 2-3 months of solid addition/subtraction practice
**Skill:** Carrying and borrowing feel automatic, not labored
**Knowledge:** Basic times tables (at least through 5s) are known
**Attitude:** Child shows confidence and expresses interest in 'harder math'
**Age:** Typically 7-9 years old, but readiness matters more than age

sections.text: The Mental Math Transition
The ultimate goal of soroban multiplication isn't speed on the physical device – it's mental calculation. After sufficient practice, children visualize the soroban in their minds.
My 10-year-old daughter now calculates 23 × 14 mentally in about 5 seconds. She describes 'seeing' the beads move in her mind. This mental visualization is the true power of soroban training.
Research shows that soroban-trained children develop enhanced activity in the brain's visual-spatial regions during calculation. They're literally seeing math differently.
My Advice to Parents
Teaching soroban multiplication requires patience. Some sessions will feel frustrating. Some weeks will show no progress. Trust the process.

items: **Don't skip prerequisites:** Solid addition is essential
**Practice daily:** 10-15 minutes beats occasional long sessions
**Celebrate accuracy:** Speed comes later, accuracy comes first
**Use the app:** Sorokid tracks progress and introduces concepts systematically
**Connect to life:** Use multiplication in real situations – shopping, cooking, games

sections.text: Multiplication on the soroban transformed how my children think about math. It can do the same for yours.

faq.question: Does my child need to know times tables first?
faq.answer: Basic times tables (1-5) definitely help. However, some children learn times tables THROUGH soroban practice, as the repetition reinforces memorization. Either approach can work.

faq.question: Is soroban multiplication faster than regular multiplication?
faq.answer: Once mastered, yes – especially for mental calculation. The place value handling becomes automatic, and mental visualization speeds up larger calculations significantly.

faq.question: How long does it take to learn multiplication on the soroban?
faq.answer: After a solid foundation in addition, basic single-digit multiplication takes 2-4 weeks. Two-digit multiplication takes 1-2 additional months. Multi-digit multiplication takes several more months of practice.

faq.question: What is soroban multiplication?
faq.answer: Soroban multiplication is a method of multiplying numbers using the Japanese abacus. It involves multiplying digit by digit, placing products in their correct place value columns, and adding the partial products together.

faq.question: When should my child start learning soroban multiplication?
faq.answer: Children should start soroban multiplication after 2-3 months of solid addition and subtraction practice, when carrying is automatic, and when they know basic times tables (at least 1-5). Most children are ready between ages 7-9.

faq.question: How do you multiply two-digit numbers on the soroban?
faq.answer: Multiply the tens digit first and set that product, then multiply the ones digit and add to the running total. For example, 23×4: First 2×4=8 (set as 80), then 3×4=12 (add to get 92).

faq.question: Why is soroban multiplication better than traditional methods?
faq.answer: Soroban multiplication makes place value visible and tactile. Children see WHY multiplication works, not just HOW to do it. This deeper understanding transfers to mental math and helps with school mathematics.

faq.question: Can soroban multiplication help with times tables memorization?
faq.answer: Yes! The repetitive nature of soroban multiplication practice reinforces times tables through use. Many children who struggle with rote memorization learn times tables more easily through soroban practice.

faq.question: What's the difference between soroban multiplication and long multiplication?
faq.answer: The underlying logic is identical – both use partial products. The difference is that soroban multiplication is performed physically with beads, making the place value and carrying process visible and concrete.

faq.question: How does soroban multiplication lead to mental math?
faq.answer: After sufficient practice, children visualize the soroban in their minds and 'see' the beads moving during calculation. This mental visualization enables rapid mental multiplication without any physical tool.

faq.question: What mistakes are common in soroban multiplication?
faq.answer: Common mistakes include forgetting place value (treating 2 tens as just 2), skipping partial products, carrying errors, and working right-to-left instead of left-to-right. Consistent practice and verbalization help prevent these.

faq.question: How long until my child can do mental multiplication?
faq.answer: Most children begin showing mental calculation abilities after 6-12 months of consistent soroban practice. The transition happens gradually as they internalize the bead visualization.

faq.question: Should my child learn multiplication on physical soroban or app?
faq.answer: Both work well. Physical sorobans provide tactile feedback, while apps like Sorokid offer progress tracking and structured lessons. Many families use both – physical for learning, app for practice.
